If a function `f` is differentiable and continuous within the open disc and its closure, then the line integral of `(z - w)â»Â¹ * f(z)` around the circle `C(c, R)` equals `2Ï€i * f(w)`.

type:
âˆ€ {E : Type u} [inst : NormedAddCommGroup E] [inst_1 : NormedSpace â„‚ E] [inst_2 : CompleteSpace E] {R : â„} {c w : â„‚}
  {f : â„‚ â†’ E},
  DiffContOnCl â„‚ f (Metric.ball c R) â†’
    w âˆˆ Metric.ball c R â†’ (âˆ® (z : â„‚) in C(c, R), (z - w)â»Â¹ â€¢ f z) = (2 * â†‘Real.pi * Complex.I) â€¢ f w
name: DiffContOnCl.circleIntegral_sub_inv_smul
docString: If a function `f` is differentiable and continuous within the open disc and its closure, then the line integral of `(z - w)â»Â¹ * f(z)` around the circle `C(c, R)` equals `2Ï€i * f(w)`.

This theorem states that for a complex function `f` that is continuous on a closed ball and differentiable in the open ball, where both balls are centered at `c` with radius `R`, and excluding a countable set `s` that does not contain a complex number `w`, the line integral of the function `f` multiplied by the inverse of `(z - w)`, around the circumference of the circle `C(c, R)`, is equal to `2Ï€i` times `f(w)`. This theorem assumes `w` does not belong to the set `s`, while the main theorem associated with this auxiliary lemma relaxes this assumption.

type:
âˆ€ {E : Type u} [inst : NormedAddCommGroup E] [inst_1 : NormedSpace â„‚ E] [inst_2 : CompleteSpace E] {R : â„} {c w : â„‚}
  {f : â„‚ â†’ E} {s : Set â„‚},
  s.Countable â†’
    w âˆˆ Metric.ball c R \ s â†’
      ContinuousOn f (Metric.closedBall c R) â†’
        (âˆ€ x âˆˆ Metric.ball c R \ s, DifferentiableAt â„‚ f x) â†’
          (âˆ® (z : â„‚) in C(c, R), (z - w)â»Â¹ â€¢ f z) = (2 * â†‘Real.pi * Complex.I) â€¢ f w
name: Complex.circleIntegral_sub_inv_smul_of_differentiable_on_off_countable_aux
docString: This theorem states that for a complex function `f` that is continuous on a closed ball and differentiable in the open ball, where both balls are centered at `c` with radius `R`, and excluding a countable set `s` that does not contain a complex number `w`, the line integral of the function `f` multiplied by the inverse of `(z - w)`, around the circumference of the circle `C(c, R)`, is equal to `2Ï€i` times `f(w)`. This theorem assumes `w` does not belong to the set `s`, while the main theorem associated with this auxiliary lemma relaxes this assumption.

If `f : â„‚ â†’ E` is continuous on the closed annulus `r â‰¤ â€–z - câ€– â‰¤ R`, `0 < r â‰¤ R`,
and is complex differentiable at all but countably many points of its interior,
then the integrals of `f z / (z - c)` (formally, `(z - c)â»Â¹ â€¢ f z`)
over the circles `â€–z - câ€– = r` and `â€–z - câ€– = R` are equal to each other.

type:

  0 < r â†’
    r â‰¤ R â†’
      âˆ€ {f : â„‚ â†’ E} {s : Set â„‚},

              (âˆ® (z : â„‚) in C(c, R), (z - c)â»Â¹ â€¢ f z) = âˆ® (z : â„‚) in C(c, r), (z - c)â»Â¹ â€¢ f z
name: Complex.circleIntegral_sub_center_inv_smul_eq_of_differentiable_on_annulus_off_countable
docString:

If a complex-valued function `f` is continuous on the closure and differentiable at all but a countable number of points in the open rectangle defined by `z` and `w`, then the integral of `f` around the boundary of the rectangle is zero.

type:
âˆ€ {E : Type u} [inst : NormedAddCommGroup E] [inst_1 : NormedSpace â„‚ E] [inst_2 : CompleteSpace E] (f : â„‚ â†’ E) (z w : â„‚)
  (s : Set â„‚),

    ContinuousOn f (Set.uIcc z.re w.re Ã—â„‚ Set.uIcc z.im w.im) â†’

          DifferentiableAt â„‚ f x) â†’
        (((âˆ« (x : â„) in z.re..w.re, f (â†‘x + â†‘z.im * Complex.I)) - âˆ« (x : â„) in z.re..w.re, f (â†‘x + â†‘w.im * Complex.I)) +
              Complex.I â€¢ âˆ« (y : â„) in z.im..w.im, f (â†‘w.re + â†‘y * Complex.I)) -
            Complex.I â€¢ âˆ« (y : â„) in z.im..w.im, f (â†‘z.re + â†‘y * Complex.I) =
          0

docString: If a complex-valued function `f` is continuous on the closure and differentiable at all but a countable number of points in the open rectangle defined by `z` and `w`, then the integral of `f` around the boundary of the rectangle is zero.

This theorem states that for any complex-valued function `f` and any complex number `c`, the contour (or line) integral of `f` around the circle centered at `c` with radius 0 is always 0. More formally, `âˆ® (z : â„‚) in C(c, 0), f z = 0`, where `C(c, 0)` is the circle centered at `c` with radius 0, `â„‚` denotes the set of complex numbers, and `E` is any normed add-commutative group that is also a normed space over the complex numbers.

Suppose that a function `f : â„‚ â†’ E` is continuous on a closed rectangle with opposite corners at
`z w : â„‚`, is *real* differentiable on the corresponding open rectangle, and
$\frac{\partial f}{\partial \bar z}$ is integrable on this rectangle. Then the integral of `f` over
the boundary of the rectangle is equal to the integral of
$2i\frac{\partial f}{\partial \bar z}=i\frac{\partial f}{\partial x}-\frac{\partial f}{\partial y}$
over the rectangle.

              Complex.I â€¢ âˆ« (y : â„) in z.im..w.im, f (â†‘w.re + â†‘y * Complex.I)) -
